is trading income taxed in sg?

there is no income tax due on sales of shares  properties  and other intangible assets in Singapore  but they become taxable when your primary purpose in buying and selling is to make profits.This especially applies to traders or dealers whose income is generated simply from conducting one’s business. Therefore  the nature and source of your business’s income need to be assessed. Gains can be considered as taxable income if the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) regards your activities as a profit-generating trade.

Oh just saw this thread. In the current high interest environment  the KF account is not worth while. Last time when it's 0.05% interest then it was super good.Think of it this way. Your 100k have interest cost of around $300 today. But the miles they give you is only 5k/MTH. That's only worth about $50.  So obviously not worth.
but people get into stocks and properties obviously with the sole intention of profitting  so it dosent make sense
UOB KF card is only good for its uncapped limited. So like deposit/ last min and can't split so many months  etc.

There is no capital gains tax in Singapore. Generally  the gains derived from the sale of a property/investment in Singapore are not subjected to tax as it is a capital gain. However  the gains may be taxable if one is in the business of trading sharesSource :https://www.aseanbriefing.com/news/a-guide-to-taxation-in-singapore/#:~:text=There%20is%20no%20capital%20gains the%20business%20of%20trading%20shares.

This should be more accurate   directly from IRAShttps://www.iras.gov.sg/taxes/individual-income-tax/basics-of-individual-income-tax/what-is-taxable-what-is-not/gains-from-sale-of-property-shares-and-financial-instruments

In short see if you part time or full time (main source of income) High likelyhood Yes taxable.
